User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux i686; rv:5.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/5.0
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux i686; rv:5.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/5.0

Most of the possible nags are stoppable with the 'Advanced' button of Javascript preferences. These are the current possibilities:

[] Move or resize existing windows
[] Raise or lower windows
[] Disable or replace context menu

The remaining two from previous versions of Firefox are now obsolete because we don't have a status bar any more. So far so good. But we still have the title text of web pages and, as you can see when you call the following link, this title text is increasingly misused in the same way as the previously annoying scrolling text in the status bar.

Here is an example of a scrolling title text

http://www.hscripts.com/scripts/JavaScript/title-scrol.php


I believe that this is not only an annoyance but may also include a security risk, because if the title of a web page is *changeable at any time* it's made easier to palm off a fake page on the user.

In any case, it seems a bit more critical than changing the text in the status bar.
So it would be a good idea to add the possibility to stop this from happening.


Reproducible: Always

comments.text:
For now these are the options that other browsers have:

Opera 11.5:
[] Allow resizing of windows
[] Allow moving of windows
[] Allow raising of windows
[] Allow lowering of windows
[] Allow changing of status field
[] Allow scripts to detect context menu events
[] Allow script to hide address bar
[] Open console on error

Chrome 10:
[] Allow all sites to run JavaScript (recommended)
[] Do not allow any site to run Javascript
Manage exceptions

I am not sure if adding more options is a good ideea. Setting status to New for other people to consider it.

I am not sure if adding more options is a good ideea. Setting status to New for other people to consider it.

While some sites might abuse it, changing the page title is an incredibly useful feature e.g. for chat webapps to display if there's a new message (especially if the tab/window currently isn't active). When adding such an option I'd rather throttle updates instead of block them completely. 1 change every 3 seconds would make people stop using those annoying scripts but not break legit apps.
